messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sukeyoshi
messages.msgSnippet: Elliott. There is nothing on Sukeyoshi in the English edition of Token Bijutsu, you might have some problems researching him as he was a pretty minor smith.
messages.messageBody:
Elliott.
There is nothing on Sukeyoshi in the English edition of Token Bijutsu, you might have some problems researching him as he was a pretty minor smith.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: elliottshogun
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, August 26, 2006 3:45 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Sukeyoshi


Alan,

I just remembered something else about Sukeyoshi - His teacher was
Masatsugu. Sukeyoshi worked in Bingo during Kei-o (1865). This is
everything I have researched to date.

Hope you can give me more. Thanks,

Elliott





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sukeyoshi
messages.msgSnippet: Elliott - Sorry, should have included that you ll find more info in Token to Rekishi, Token Bijutsu and Token Kaishi where various articles have appeared.
messages.messageBody:
Elliott -
Sorry, should have included that you'll find more info in Token to
Rekishi, Token Bijutsu and Token Kaishi where various articles have
appeared. Since these are Japanese references and I am sorry I do not
have the pertinent numbers at hand, I would look for 'Art and The
Sword'. The publication of the JSSUS, I believe they did one issue on
Yokoyama Bizen...
-t

On Aug 25, 2006, at 4:06 PM, elliottshogun wrote:

> I was reading Alan and Richards discussion about Edo Tosho Tsuba being
> made by swordsmiths/armor makers. I learned (at the SF Token Kai)from
> Robert Haynes that a tsuba I had (I could not read the signature)was
> made by Sukeyoshi. It is signed Sukeyoshi Saku. Robert told me he was
> a swordsmith who made tsuba and signed his 'Suke' differently than his
> swords.
>
> Where can I read more about Sukeyoshi? Do you have any knowledge of
> this smith?
>
> Thanks,
> Elliott
>
>
>



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sukeyoshi
messages.msgSnippet: Elliott et al - That would be Yokoyama Sukeyoshi, who worked in Bizen and Fukuyama Bingo on the cusp of the Modern era. His dated works are from Keio (1865)
messages.messageBody:
Elliott et al -
That would be Yokoyama Sukeyoshi, who worked in Bizen and Fukuyama
Bingo on the cusp of the Modern era. His dated works are from Keio
(1865) and Meiji(1868). Sounds like a very cool tsuba, can't wait to
see the pictures. I have to admit, like Richard, I enjoy those late
Edo swordsmiths tsuba. I just bought a papered 11th generation
Yasutsugu tsuba at last weekends Taikai.
Addressing Richards question, the Yasutsugu tsuba I have seen are
rather plain, while Masahide seems to have put a lot of work into his
tsuba. Pure speculation but I would think he would have presented the
tsuba as a separate independant work. Who would want all that work
overshadowed by a blade or vice versa. I base it solely on my ill-
informed ideas of what a craftsman like Masahide was all about.
FWIW
-t

messages.subject: Re: Sukeyoshi
messages.msgSnippet: Alan, Robert Haynes showed me (by drawing out on paper)the different kanji for Suke that this smith used. It s very hard to see on the tsuba. I will attempt
messages.messageBody:
Alan,

Robert Haynes showed me (by drawing out on paper)the different kanji
for 'Suke' that this smith used. It's very hard to see on the tsuba.
I will attempt a better photo. This description may help; the legs
of the kanji (suke) are spread apart at the top (like a vee). I have
the little post-it that Robert drew the kanji on.

Let me work on this. I appreciate your help.

Elliott

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Alan Bale" <abale@...> wrote:
>
> Elliott,
> There were many Sukeyoshi smiths, if you want to know more then we
need to know which kanji were used.
> Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: elliottshogun
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, August 26, 2006 12:06 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Sukeyoshi


I was reading Alan and Richards discussion about Edo Tosho Tsuba being
made by swordsmiths/armor makers. I learned (at the SF Token Kai)from
Robert Haynes that a tsuba I had (I could not read the signature)was
made by Sukeyoshi. It is signed Sukeyoshi Saku. Robert told me he was
a swordsmith who made tsuba and signed his 'Suke' differently than his
swords.

Where can I read more about Sukeyoshi? Do you have any knowledge of
this smith?

Thanks,
Elliott





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Sukeyoshi
messages.msgSnippet: I was reading Alan and Richards discussion about Edo Tosho Tsuba being made by swordsmiths/armor makers. I learned (at the SF Token Kai)from Robert Haynes that
messages.messageBody:
I was reading Alan and Richards discussion about Edo Tosho Tsuba being
made by swordsmiths/armor makers. I learned (at the SF Token Kai)from
Robert Haynes that a tsuba I had (I could not read the signature)was
made by Sukeyoshi. It is signed Sukeyoshi Saku. Robert told me he was
a swordsmith who made tsuba and signed his 'Suke' differently than his
swords.

Where can I read more about Sukeyoshi? Do you have any knowledge of
this smith?

Thanks,
Elliott
